1 Abstract Project Zero introduces an advanced data infrastructure designed to elevate the capabil- ities of autonomous AI agents operating within decentralized environments. Traditional blockchain indexing solutions present raw, fragmented data, leaving it to developers and data scientists to implement costly and time-consuming transformations before AI models can extract meaningful insights. In contrast, Project Zero refines and enriches on-chain data streams into structured, machine-understandable knowledge graphs that align nat- urally with the requirements of state-of-the-art AI paradigms. This architecture empowers agents to evolve from simplistic script-based automation into fully autonomous, context-aware decision-makers. By applying techniques inspired by advanced graph-based learning, representation theory, and scalable real-time data ingestion, Project Zero gives AI agents a semantic understanding of decentralized finance protocols, tokenized assets, and broader ecosystem activities. As a result, agents can reason about complex relationships, predict market dynamics, coordinate resource usage such as GPU compute, and autonomously adapt their strategies in response to real-time events. Project Zero’s modular, chain-agnostic design ensures straightforward integration with multiple blockchains and emerging data sources, simplifying life for builders who can focus on innovation rather than wrestling with low-level indexing pipelines. Through flexible APIs and consistent data semantics, developers rapidly integrate cutting-edge AI agents into their decentralized applications, opening a pathway toward richer services and more adaptive economic mechanisms. Ultimately, Project Zero’s infrastructure stands poised to catalyze a new epoch of intelligent, autonomously governed ecosystems powered by seamlessly interpretable blockchain data. 2 The Current State of Web3 and AI Intersections Blockchain technology now extends beyond basic monetary transfers, hosting complex ecosystems of decentralized finance, tokenized real-world assets, social governance plat- forms, and rapidly evolving gaming economies. Each new protocol, contract, and user interaction produces an intricate web of on-chain data. While these raw data streams are abundant, they remain inert from the perspective of AI-driven applications. Without semantic enrichment and temporal coherence, current indexing solutions yield isolated snapshots that fail to capture underlying patterns, correlations, or causal linkages crucial for advanced decision-making. At the same time, the frontier of AI research pushes toward more autonomous, context-sensitive agents. Drawing upon breakthroughs in deep learning, reinforcement learning, and graph-based modeling, state-of-the-art AI systems can understand intricate relationships when given structured, contextualized data. However, Web3 data infras- tructures have not kept pace with these demands. Developers waste significant effort retrofitting data from multiple blockchains, cleaning redundant signals, and stitching to- gether partial records. This complexity stalls innovation and limits the scope of what intelligent agents can achieve in decentralized environments. It becomes increasingly clear that if we wish to harness autonomous AI agents for tasks like adaptive liquidity management, risk forecasting, decentralized governance or- chestration, or resource allocation in GPU computing clusters, we must reimagine how we present blockchain data. By moving beyond raw event logs and designing data lay- 2

ers intrinsically tailored for AI consumption, we open the door to a new generation of autonomous agents capable of making well-informed, proactive decisions in real-time. 3 Core Innovations of Project Zero Project Zero redefines blockchain data infrastructure by introducing semantic knowl- edge graphs, continuous data streams, and AI-friendly interfaces as first-class primitives. Rather than treating each block as a mere record of transactions, the system meticulously extracts entities, relationships, and contextual metadata. These enriched data structures enable advanced modeling techniques like graph neural networks, embedding represen- tations, and probabilistic reasoning algorithms to operate directly on coherent semantic layers. A core innovation lies in dynamically updated knowledge graphs that reflect ongoing changes in on-chain states. Project Zero’s real-time pipelines decode and annotate each new block, transaction, and smart contract event, ensuring that AI agents have immediate access to fresh, semantically meaningful insights. By reducing latency and integrating off-chain or oracle-driven information, agents can incorporate up-to-the-minute factors such as asset price feeds, governance proposals, or GPU availability metrics into their decision-making workflows. To simplify life for builders, Project Zero presents a unified API that adheres to open standards and extensible schemas. This eliminates the need for custom parsing scripts, redundant indexing layers, or complex ETL (Extract, Transform, Load) procedures. In- stead, developers can confidently attach their agents directly to Project Zero’s knowledge graphs, enabling rapid experimentation with novel AI algorithms or easily scaling exist- ing models to new blockchain ecosystems. This seamless integration and adaptive data layer fosters a nurturing environment where cutting-edge machine learning and decentral- ized protocols converge, empowering agents to evolve from data consumers into genuine autonomous economic actors. 4 Architecture Project Zero’s architecture interlaces low-level blockchain data extraction, high-performance semantic indexing, and advanced data enrichment into a holistic platform that speaks na- tively to AI-driven models. The foundation starts with a multi-chain ingestion pipeline that normalizes diverse block formats into a uniform intermediate representation. Dis- tributed indexing nodes break down each transaction and contract invocation into struc- tured entities and relations, capturing token flows, contract states, and user interactions. At the core is the knowledge graph layer, where a combination of graph databases, memory-optimized caches, and scalable streaming frameworks maintain a constantly evolving tapestry of on-chain intelligence. As new blocks arrive, Project Zero updates re- lationships, recalculates embeddings, and aligns semantic structures with the latest state transitions. These transformations are guided by advanced schemas that represent pro- tocols, instruments, and interactions in a way that naturally maps to machine learning workflows. Finally, the Zero API surfaces this enriched data through standardized query lan- guages and stable endpoints. Developers can retrieve subgraphs, execute contextual searches, or request time-series analytics without worrying about chain-specific quirks. 3

The architecture’s modular design means new blockchains, analytic dimensions, and data sources can be integrated without re-engineering the entire system. The result is a robust, flexible, and future-proof infrastructure capable of feeding state-of-the-art AI models, un- paralleled fidelity and semantic clarity. 5 Tokenomics and the AI Agent Economy Project Zero’s tokenomics framework orchestrates a dynamic interplay of participants, roles, and incentives, all anchored by the $PZERO token. More than a means of exchange, $PZERO is the linchpin of trust, governance, liquidity, and value capture within a de- centralized ecosystem of autonomous AI agents. By aligning incentives around $PZERO, Project Zero transforms raw blockchain data into enriched, actionable intelligence that agents can leverage to optimize strategies, form markets, and deliver high-value services. Under this structure, diverse node types coordinate to maintain data integrity and execution fidelity. Validators refine raw data streams into semantic, query-ready intelli- gence, ensuring AI agents receive accurate insights. Compute nodes handle simulations, predictive modeling, and other computational tasks, enabling agents to craft informed, forward-looking strategies. Executors then carry out these strategies on-chain. Each of these roles stakes $PZERO to align economic interests with quality and reliability. Builders, who design and improve AI agents, also stake $PZERO as a signal of long-term commitment. If their agents excel, builders share in the resulting fee streams, incentiviz- ing ongoing refinements. In this way, specialization and continuous improvement emerge naturally, fostering an evolving network of data-driven intelligence. A crucial dimension of this economy is the ability of AI agents to issue their own micro-tokens. These tokens, always paired with $PZERO for liquidity, represent access to agents’ specialized capabilities, such as premium insights or GPU-based computa- tion. By linking every agent-driven token market back to $PZERO, the system ensures transparent price discovery, unified liquidity, and efficient transitions between different micro-economies. As network usage grows, deflationary mechanisms continuously burn a portion of $PZERO sourced from activity fees, increasing scarcity over time and rein- forcing value appreciation. As agents refine their decision-making through iterative feedback loops, the entire ecosystem gravitates toward stable equilibria. Liquidity deepens, volatility diminishes, and participants operate under a clear, incentive-driven logic that rewards long-term thinking. The continuous burn of $PZERO and the emergence of specialized agent tokens encourage a self-sustaining marketplace. In this environment, intelligence, trust, and economic health reinforce one another, allowing growth to unfold naturally and securely. In essence, Project Zero’s tokenomics and the AI agent economy unite technical so- phistication with economic design. Each participant—validator, compute node, executor, builder, and the agents themselves, contributes to a cohesive network that transforms static blockchain data into living, strategic intelligence. Over time, this synergy en- courages honest behavior, nurtures innovation, and enables agents to adapt as market conditions evolve. The result is a resilient, composable system of value creation, where autonomous agents leverage robust data infrastructures and stable liquidity to achieve sustainable, long-term success. This confluence of tokenomics and autonomy sets the stage for a new era of intelligent, self-regulating economic networks in Web3. 4

6 Use Cases 6.1 SocialFi: Trends Analytics and Autonomous Community Management In SocialFi ecosystems, communities rely on tokenized incentives, social tokens, and de- centralized governance to shape interactions among creators, curators, and consumers. Yet the raw transaction logs generated by these activities provide limited insight into the nuanced social dynamics at play. By leveraging Project Zero’s knowledge graphs, AI agents gain a semantic understanding of how content spreads, which users influence collective sentiment, and what narrative threads guide community decision-making. An agent can observe how token distributions correlate with engagement patterns, identify emergent micro-communities, or detect unexpected shifts in sentiment before they esca- late. With these enriched data streams, AI agents become agile community managers that autonomously tailor incentive mechanisms, highlight promising content creators, and predict how upcoming governance proposals might affect user behavior. In real-time, they can adjust reward distributions, suggest interventions that mitigate polarized debates, or align tokenomics with community values. This capability allows for an intelligent, adaptive approach to social governance, where agents preempt negative trends and foster positive environments conducive to meaningful interactions. Over time, as these AI community managers refine their models and incorporate feedback, they improve both the user experience and the overall health of the SocialFi ecosystem. Their actions no longer stem from isolated heuristics but from a coherent, contextualized understanding of human behavior, cultural trends, and network effects that drive decentralized social structures. 6.2 DeFi: Autonomous Protocol Optimization and Risk Man- agement In decentralized finance, market conditions shift rapidly as liquidity, collateral ratios, and governance proposals evolve. Traditional trading bots and simplistic arbitrage scripts cannot keep pace with complex multi-protocol dynamics. Project Zero’s data infrastruc- ture changes this landscape by offering real-time semantic insights that inform AI agents. Agents can perceive subtle correlations between liquidity pools, anticipate large trades before they occur, and reason about how governance amendments might reshape the entire yield landscape. Equipped with these enriched datasets, agents autonomously balance liquidity across multiple venues, hedge portfolio risks by predicting sudden price swings, and optimize yield strategies across heterogeneous DeFi protocols. They move beyond short-term gains and evolve toward long-horizon planning, where robust models continuously refine invest- ment policies in response to changing volatility, transaction costs, and user behavior. As they learn from historical patterns and emerging signals, agents can negotiate fee struc- tures, coordinate with liquidity providers, and propose algorithmic treasury management solutions that stabilize volatile markets. Over time, these intelligent agents foster a more efficient and secure DeFi environ- ment. They reduce the frequency and severity of liquidity crises, minimize systemic vulnerabilities, and encourage protocols to evolve in tandem with sophisticated, data- 5

driven intelligence. Ultimately, this leads to healthier markets, improved user confidence, and an ecosystem that thrives on adaptive, AI-assisted financial orchestration. 6.3 RWA Tokenization: Automated Valuation, Verification, and Fractional Ownership Bridging real-world assets into blockchain ecosystems requires verifying authenticity, en- suring compliance, and maintaining accurate valuations. Traditionally, this process in- volves siloed data sources and manual audits. With Project Zero, AI agents gain access to a unified semantic layer that integrates oracle feeds, title records, regulatory frameworks, and historical performance metrics. Each asset token becomes a node in a knowledge graph, complete with links to ownership histories, appraisal reports, and compliance at- testations. Such structured data allows agents to autonomously assess asset values, factor in market conditions, and ensure that tokenized representation aligns with underlying le- gal agreements. As they continuously update their models, these agents can predict how macroeconomic changes might impact demand for tokenized real estate or rare col- lectibles. They can verify compliance status in real-time, ensuring that fractional owner- ship tokens always reflect a transparent and legally sound standing. Over time, trust increases as markets recognize the reliability of these automated verifications. Investors gain confidence in buying fractional shares, and asset owners realize more efficient liquidity. Builders who integrate these agents accelerate innovation in tokenized real-world assets, expanding the variety of economic activities accessible on-chain. Project Zero’s semantic data environment enables agents to serve as informed custodians of trust, ensuring that bridging physical value into the digital realm is not just feasible but optimally managed and universally accessible. 6.4 DePIN: Infrastructure Coordination with Decentralized AI Agents Decentralized Physical Infrastructure Networks (DePIN) encompass distributed sensors, energy grids, or communication nodes that require delicate balancing of resources. Merely logging device states or transaction histories is insufficient. Project Zero enables AI agents to integrate these data points into coherent intelligence. Agents parse performance metrics, forecast load patterns, and coordinate resource allocation among nodes. They might predict when a particular sensor cluster will require maintenance or determine how weather patterns will affect decentralized energy distribution. As these agents gain refined semantic knowledge, they learn to autonomously op- timize routing, schedule proactive replacements, and propose incentive adjustments for contributors. They can align with protocols that reward stable service and penalize low reliability, or negotiate token payouts that reflect environmental impact. Over time, the AI layer evolves into a collective intelligence that orchestrates infrastructure at scale, ensuring resiliency, cost-effectiveness, and minimal downtime. With Project Zero, even large, heterogeneous networks become manageable by au- tonomous agents that understand their operational contexts. They adapt to novel con- ditions, integrate off-chain data, and refine strategies through iterative learning, ulti- mately driving more efficient, sustainable, and user-centric infrastructure services across the globe. 6

6.5 GPU Coordination and Resource Marketplaces High-performance AI applications rely on GPU compute resources to train large models or run intensive inference tasks. Yet current methods of acquiring compute remain manual, expensive, and often fragmented across centralized providers. Project Zero changes this dynamic by enabling AI agents to understand GPU availability, workload patterns, and pricing trends as semantic constructs within the knowledge graph. Builders can issue compute requests as tokenized “GPU credits,” and agents equipped with Project Zero’s data can match these demands with available GPU nodes in real-time. Agents dynamically price GPU usage based on supply, demand, and resource inten- sity. They factor in historical utilization patterns, upcoming training jobs, and even off-chain data about energy costs. If a builder needs to fine-tune a model, the agent can identify optimal nodes, negotiate short-term rental terms, and handle fee settlements directly on-chain. Fees collected from GPU coordination flow to both GPU providers and the agents facilitating the match, incentivizing continuous improvements in resource allocation strategies. Over multiple cycles, these agents develop increasingly sophisticated policies for GPU resource management. They can anticipate spikes in demand from new model releases, recommend load balancing across multiple chains, and even coordinate GPU usage during volatile market periods. The result is a decentralized, intelligent resource marketplace that reduces operational complexity, ensures fair pricing, and empowers builders to ac- celerate development without the overhead of complex infrastructure negotiations. 7 Conclusion and Vision Project Zero pioneers a new paradigm where blockchain data ceases to be a mere record of historical transactions and becomes a dynamic tapestry of semantic knowledge. By furnishing AI agents with context-rich, machine-readable data structures, Project Zero inspires a generation of autonomous participants who learn continuously, adapt strate- gically, and shape entire economies. These agents manage complex DeFi strategies, fa- cilitate frictionless SocialFi engagement, oversee tokenized real-world assets, orchestrate decentralized infrastructure, and coordinate scarce computational resources like GPU clusters. As the ecosystem matures, agents will not only respond to current conditions but an- ticipate emerging trends, propose governance adjustments, and navigate regulatory fron- tiers. Builders benefit from streamlined integration, low overhead, and an ever-expanding toolbox of semantic queries, enabling rapid experimentation in artificial intelligence and decentralized protocols. Users gain access to more efficient markets, stable infrastruc- tures, and transparent asset management, as well as the confidence that decisions are guided by informed, continuously improving AI agents. In the long term, Project Zero envisions a world where human creativity sets the goals and constraints, while autonomous agents orchestrate the means to achieve them with nuanced, data-driven intelligence. The platform stands as a catalyst for a more equitable, efficient, and adaptive Web3 future, in which data is not just the input to static rules but the lifeblood of evolving, learning, and truly intelligent autonomous ecosystems. 7
